name: Chyulu Hills National Park
shortDescription: One of Earth's youngest volcanic mountain ranges (under 500 years old) featuring Leviathan Cave - Africa's longest lava tube at 11km - with stunning Kilimanjaro views and grassland elephants.
fullDescription:
The Chyulu Hills are a picturesque range of volcanic hills stretching southeast from Nairobi, situated between Amboseli and Tsavo National Parks. These are some of the youngest mountains on Earth, formed by volcanic activity less than 500 years ago, with the last eruption occurring in 1855. The hills are a string of dormant and extinct volcanoes creating verdant rolling landscapes unlike anywhere else in Kenya.

The hills contain Leviathan Cave (also known as Kisula caves), considered the longest and deepest lava tube in Africa at approximately 11 kilometers (6.8 miles) long. These lava tubes - cylindrical passages hollowed out by hot molten lava - are found throughout the hills and offer unique spelunking opportunities with expert guides. The cave system was segmented by the movement of tectonic plates, creating one of the world's most remarkable subterranean landscapes.

With stunning landscapes and views of Mount Kilimanjaro dominating the southern horizon, the Chyulu Hills is one of the best places in Kenya for hiking and mountain activities. On clear mornings, Kilimanjaro's snowcapped peak creates breathtaking photography opportunities, while to the north, Mount Kenya is visible. Chyulu Hills National Park protects rolling grasslands, indigenous forests, and remarkable biodiversity.

Chyulu Hills is primarily known for its magnificent bull elephants roaming the grasslands, picturesque views of Kilimanjaro, and exclusivity - the area receives very few tourists, providing an intimate wilderness experience. The combination of volcanic landscapes, mountain hiking, cave exploration, and world-class lodges makes Chyulu Hills a perfect addition to any Kenya itinerary.
